**Haswell** is the [codename](/wiki/List_of_Intel_codenames "List of Intel
codenames") for a [processor](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central
processing unit") [microarchitecture](/wiki/Microarchitecture
"Microarchitecture") developed by [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel") as the "fourth-
generation core" successor to the [Ivy
Bridge](/wiki/Ivy_Bridge_\(microarchitecture\) "Ivy Bridge
\(microarchitecture\)") microarchitecture.[1] Intel officially announced
[CPUs](/wiki/CPU "CPU") based on this microarchitecture on June 4, 2013 at
[Computex Taipei](/wiki/Computex_Taipei "Computex Taipei") 2013,[2] while a
working Haswell chip was demonstrated at the 2011 [Intel Developer
Forum](/wiki/Intel_Developer_Forum "Intel Developer Forum").[3] With Haswell,
which uses a [22 nm](/wiki/22_nanometer "22 nanometer") process,[4] Intel also
introduced low-power processors designed for convertible or "hybrid"
[ultrabooks](/wiki/Ultrabooks "Ultrabooks"), designated by the "Y" suffix.

Haswell CPUs are used in conjunction with the [Intel 8 Series
chipsets](/wiki/Intel_8_Series_chipsets "Intel 8 Series chipsets"), [Intel 9
Series chipsets](/wiki/Intel_9_Series_chipsets "Intel 9 Series chipsets"), and
[Intel C220 series chipsets](/wiki/Intel_Xeon_chipsets#Haswell-
based_Xeon_chipsets "Intel Xeon chipsets").

##
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Design")]

The Haswell architecture is specifically designed[5] to optimize the power
savings and performance benefits from the move to [FinFET](/wiki/FinFET
"FinFET") (non-planar, "3D") transistors on the improved 22 nm process
node.[6]

Haswell has been launched in three major forms:[7]

  * Desktop version ([LGA 1150](/wiki/LGA_1150 "LGA 1150") socket and the new [LGA 2011-v3](/wiki/LGA_2011-v3 "LGA 2011-v3") socket): _Haswell-DT_
  * Mobile/Laptop version ([PGA](/wiki/Pin_grid_array "Pin grid array") socket): _Haswell-MB_
  * [BGA](/wiki/Ball_grid_array "Ball grid array") version: 
    * 47 W and 57 W [TDP](/wiki/Thermal_design_power "Thermal design power") classes: _Haswell-H_ (for "All-in-one" systems, Mini-ITX form factor motherboards, and other small footprint formats)
    * 13.5 W and 15 W TDP classes ([MCP](/wiki/Multi-chip_package "Multi-chip package")): _Haswell-ULT_ (for Intel's UltraBook platform)
    * 10 W TDP class (SoC): _Haswell-ULX_ (for tablets and certain UltraBook-class implementations)

###
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Notes")]

  * ULT = _Ultra Low TDP_ ; ULX = _Ultra Low eXtreme_ TDP
  * Only certain quad-core variants and BGA R-series [stock keeping units](/wiki/Stock_keeping_unit "Stock keeping unit") (SKUs) receive GT3e ([Intel Iris Pro](/wiki/Intel_Iris_Pro "Intel Iris Pro") 5200) integrated graphics. All other models have GT3 ([Intel HD](/wiki/Intel_HD "Intel HD") 5000 or [Intel Iris](/wiki/Intel_Iris "Intel Iris") 5100), GT2 (Intel HD 4200, 4400, 4600, P4600 or P4700) or GT1 (Intel HD Graphics) integrated graphics.[8] See also [Intel HD and Iris Graphics](/wiki/Intel_HD_and_Iris_Graphics "Intel HD and Iris Graphics") for more details.
  * Due to the low power requirements of tablet and UltraBook platforms, Haswell-ULT and Haswell-ULX are only available in dual-core configurations. All other versions come as dual- or quad-core variants.

###
Performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Performance")]

Compared to [Ivy Bridge](/wiki/Ivy_Bridge_\(microarchitecture\) "Ivy Bridge
\(microarchitecture\)"):

  * Approximately 8% faster [vector processing](/wiki/Vector_processor "Vector processor")[9]
  * Up to 5% faster single-threaded performance
  * 6% faster multi-threaded performance
  * Desktop variants of Haswell draw between 8% and 23% more power under load than Ivy Bridge.[9][10][11]
  * A 6% increase in sequential CPU [performance](/wiki/Computer_performance "Computer performance") (eight execution ports per core versus six)[9]
  * Up to 20% performance increase over the integrated HD4000 [GPU](/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing unit") (Haswell HD4600 vs Ivy Bridge's built-in [Intel HD4000](/wiki/Intel_HD_Graphics "Intel HD Graphics"))[9]
  * Total performance improvement on average is about 3%[9]
  * Around 15 °C hotter than Ivy Bridge, while clock frequencies of over 4.6 GHz are achievable[12][13][14][15][16][17]

##
Technology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Technology")]

See also: [Intel HD Graphics](/wiki/Intel_HD_Graphics "Intel HD Graphics")

### Features carried over from Ivy
Bridge[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Features carried over from Ivy Bridge")]

  * [22 nm](/wiki/22_nanometer "22 nanometer") manufacturing process[4]
  * 3D [_Tri-Gate_ FinFET transistors](/wiki/Tri-Gate_transistor "Tri-Gate transistor")[18]
  * [Micro-operation cache](/wiki/Micro-operation_cache "Micro-operation cache")(Uop Cache) capable of storing 1.5 K [micro-operations](/wiki/Micro-operation "Micro-operation") (approximately 6 KB in size)[19]
  * 14- to 19-stage [instruction pipeline](/wiki/Instruction_pipeline "Instruction pipeline"), depending on the micro-operation cache hit or miss (an approach used in the even earlier [Sandy Bridge](/wiki/Sandy_Bridge_\(microarchitecture\) "Sandy Bridge \(microarchitecture\)") microarchitecture)[19]
  * Mainstream variants are up to quad-core.[20]
  * Native support for [dual-channel](/wiki/Multi-channel_memory_architecture "Multi-channel memory architecture") [DDR3/DDR3L](/wiki/DDR3_SDRAM "DDR3 SDRAM") memory,[21] with up to 32 GB of [RAM](/wiki/RAM "RAM") on LGA 1150 variants
  * 64 KB (32 KB Instruction + 32 KB Data) L1 cache and 256 KB L2 cache per core[22]
  * A total of 16 [PCI Express](/wiki/PCI_Express "PCI Express") 3.0 lanes on LGA 1150 variants[23]

### New
features[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: New features")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Fully_Integrated_Voltage_Regulator.svg/220px-
Fully_Integrated_Voltage_Regulator.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Fully_Integrated_Voltage_Regulator.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Fully_Integrated_Voltage_Regulator.svg "Enlarge")

Haswell featured a [Fully Integrated Voltage
Regulator](/wiki/Fully_Integrated_Voltage_Regulator "Fully Integrated Voltage
Regulator").

  * Wider core:[24] fourth [arithmetic logic unit](/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit "Arithmetic logic unit") (ALU), third [address generation unit](/wiki/Address_generation_unit "Address generation unit") (AGU),[25][26][27] second [branch execution unit](/w/index.php?title=Branch_execution_unit&action=edit&redlink=1 "Branch execution unit \(page does not exist\)") (BEU), deeper buffers, higher cache bandwidth, improved front-end and [memory controller](/wiki/Memory_controller "Memory controller"), higher load/store bandwidth.
  * [New instructions](/wiki/Haswell_New_Instructions "Haswell New Instructions")[28] (HNI, includes [Advanced Vector Extensions 2](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions_2 "Advanced Vector Extensions 2") (AVX2), [gather](/wiki/Gather-scatter_\(vector_addressing\) "Gather-scatter \(vector addressing\)"), [BMI1, BMI2, ABM](/wiki/Bit_Manipulation_Instruction_Sets "Bit Manipulation Instruction Sets") and [FMA3](/wiki/FMA_instruction_set "FMA instruction set") support).[29]
  * The instruction decode queue, which holds instructions after they have been decoded, is no longer statically partitioned between the two threads that each core can service.[19]
  * New sockets and chipsets: 
    * LGA 1150 for desktops, and rPGA947 and BGA1364 for the mobile market.[30]
    * [Z97](/wiki/Z97 "Z97") (performance) and [H97](/wiki/H97 "H97") (mainstream) [chipsets](/wiki/Chipset "Chipset") for the Haswell Refresh and [Broadwell](/wiki/Broadwell_\(microarchitecture\) "Broadwell \(microarchitecture\)"), in Q2 2014.[31]
    * [LGA 2011-v3](/wiki/LGA_2011-v3 "LGA 2011-v3") with [X99](/wiki/Intel_X99 "Intel X99") chipset for the enthusiast-class desktop platform _Haswell-E_.[32]
  * Intel [Transactional Synchronization Extensions](/wiki/Transactional_Synchronization_Extensions "Transactional Synchronization Extensions") (TSX) for the Haswell-EX variant. In August 2014 Intel announced that a bug exists in the TSX implementation on the current [steppings](/wiki/Stepping_level "Stepping level") of Haswell, Haswell-E, Haswell-EP and early Broadwell CPUs, which resulted in disabling the TSX feature on affected CPUs via a [microcode](/wiki/Microcode "Microcode") update.[33][34][35][36]
  * Hardware graphics support for [Direct3D 11.1](/wiki/Direct3D_11.1 "Direct3D 11.1") and [OpenGL](/wiki/OpenGL "OpenGL") 4.3.[37][38][39] Intel 10.18.14.4889 driver is the last planned driver release on Windows 7/8.1.[40]
  * [DDR4](/wiki/DDR4_SDRAM "DDR4 SDRAM") for the enthusiast and enterprise/server segments[41] and for the Enthusiast-Class Desktop Platform Haswell-E[42]
  * Variable Base clock (BClk)[43] like [LGA 2011](/wiki/LGA_2011 "LGA 2011").[44]
  * Four versions of the integrated GPU: GT1, GT2, GT3 and GT3e, where GT3 version has 40 execution units (EUs). Haswell's predecessor, Ivy Bridge, has a maximum of 16 EUs. GT3e version with 40 EUs and on-package 128 MB of embedded DRAM ([eDRAM](/wiki/EDRAM "EDRAM")), called [Crystalwell](/wiki/Crystalwell "Crystalwell"), is available only in mobile H-[SKUs](/wiki/Stock_keeping_unit "Stock keeping unit") and desktop ([BGA](/wiki/Ball_grid_array "Ball grid array")-only) R-SKUs. Effectively, this eDRAM is a Level 4 cache; it is shared dynamically between the on-die GPU and CPU, and serving as a [victim cache](/wiki/Victim_cache "Victim cache") to the CPU's Level 3 cache.[45][46][47][48][49]
  * Optional support for [Thunderbolt](/wiki/Thunderbolt_\(interface\) "Thunderbolt \(interface\)") technology and Thunderbolt 2.0[50][51]
  * [Fully integrated voltage regulator](/wiki/Fully_integrated_voltage_regulator "Fully integrated voltage regulator") (FIVR), thereby moving some of the components from [motherboard](/wiki/Motherboard "Motherboard") onto the CPU.[52][53][54]
  * New advanced power-saving system; due to Haswell's new low-power C6 and C7 sleep states, not all [power supply units](/wiki/Power_supply_unit_\(computer\) "Power supply unit \(computer\)") (PSUs) are suitable for computers with Haswell CPUs.[55][56]
  * 37, 47, 57 W [thermal design power](/wiki/Thermal_design_power "Thermal design power") (TDP) mobile processors.[20]
  * 35, 45, 65, 84, 88, 95 and 130–140 W (high-end, Haswell-E) TDP desktop processors.[20]
  * 15 W or 11.5W TDP processors for the [Ultrabook](/wiki/Ultrabook "Ultrabook") platform (multi-chip package like [Westmere](/wiki/Westmere_\(microarchitecture\) "Westmere \(microarchitecture\)"))[57] leading to reduced heat, which results in thinner as well as lighter Ultrabooks, but the performance level is slightly lower than the 17 W version.[58]
  * Shrink of the [Platform Controller Hub](/wiki/Platform_Controller_Hub "Platform Controller Hub") (PCH), from [65 nm](/wiki/65_nanometer "65 nanometer") to [32 nm](/wiki/32_nanometer "32 nanometer").[59]

     [Translation lookaside buffer](/wiki/Translation_lookaside_buffer "Translation lookaside buffer") sizes[60][61] Cache  | Page size   
---|---  
Name | Level | 4 KB | 2 MB | 1 GB   
DTLB | 1st | 64 | 32 | 4   
ITLB | 1st | 128 | 8 / logical core | none   
STLB  | 2nd  | 1024  | none   
  
### Server processors
features[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Server processors features")]

  * [Haswell-EP](/wiki/Haswell-EP "Haswell-EP") variant, released in September 2014, with up to 18 cores and marketed as the Xeon E5-1600 v3 and Xeon E5-2600 v3 series.[62]
  * Haswell-EX variant, released in May 2015, with 18 cores and functioning TSX.[35][63][64]
  * A new [cache](/wiki/CPU_cache "CPU cache") design.
  * Up to 35 MB total unified cache ([last level cache](/wiki/Last_level_cache "Last level cache"), LLC) for Haswell-EP[65] and up to 40 MB for Haswell-EX.
  * [LGA 2011-v3](/wiki/LGA_2011-v3 "LGA 2011-v3") socket replaces [LGA 2011](/wiki/LGA_2011 "LGA 2011") for the Haswell EP; the new socket has the same number of pins, but it is keyed differently due to electrical incompatibility.[66][67][68]
  * The already launched [Xeon E3 v3](/wiki/Xeon_E3_v3 "Xeon E3 v3") Haswells will get a refresh in spring 2014,[69] together with a refreshed Intel [C220 series PCH](/wiki/Intel_Xeon_chipsets#Single_processor_Haswell-based_Xeon_chipsets "Intel Xeon chipsets") chipset.[70]
  * TDP up to 160 W for Haswell-EP.[71]
  * Haswell-EP models with ten and more cores support _cluster on die_ (COD) operation mode,[72] allowing CPU's multiple columns of cores and [last level cache](/wiki/Last_level_cache "Last level cache") (LLC) slices to be logically divided into what is presented as two [non-uniform memory access](/wiki/Non-uniform_memory_access "Non-uniform memory access") (NUMA) CPUs to the operating system. By keeping data and instructions local to the "partition" of CPU which is processing them, therefore decreasing the LLC access latency, COD brings performance improvements to NUMA-aware operating systems and applications.[73]

### Haswell
Refresh[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Haswell Refresh")]

Around the middle of 2014, Intel released a refresh of Haswell, simply titled
_Haswell Refresh_. When compared to the original Haswell CPUs lineup, Haswell
Refresh CPUs offer a modest increase in clock frequencies, usually of 100
MHz.[74] Haswell Refresh CPUs are supported by Intel's _9 Series_ chipsets
(Z97 and H97, codenamed [Wildcat Point](/wiki/Wildcat_Point "Wildcat Point")),
while motherboards with _8 Series_ chipsets (codenamed [Lynx
Point](/wiki/Lynx_Point "Lynx Point")) usually require a BIOS update to
support Haswell Refresh CPUs.[75]

The CPUs codenamed _Devil 's Canyon_, covering the i5 and i7 K-series
[SKUs](/wiki/Stock_keeping_unit "Stock keeping unit"), employ a new and
improved [thermal interface material](/wiki/Thermal_interface_material
"Thermal interface material") (TIM) called next-generation polymer thermal
interface material (_NGPTIM_). This improved TIM reduces the CPU's operating
temperatures and improves the overclocking potential, as something that had
been problematic since the introduction of Ivy Bridge.[76] Other changes for
the Devil's Canyon CPUs include a TDP increase to 88 W, additional decoupling
capacitors to help smooth out the outputs from the fully integrated voltage
regulator (FIVR), and support for the [VT-d](/wiki/VT-d "VT-d") that was
previously limited to non-K-series SKUs.[77]
[TSX](/wiki/Transactional_Synchronization_Extensions "Transactional
Synchronization Extensions") was another feature brought over from the non-K-
series SKUs, until August 2014 when a microcode update disabled TSX due to a
bug that was discovered in its implementation.[35][36]

## List of Haswell
processors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: List of Haswell processors")]

### Desktop
processors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Desktop processors")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Intel_Haswell_4771_CPU.jpg/220px-
Intel_Haswell_4771_CPU.jpg)](/wiki/File:Intel_Haswell_4771_CPU.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Intel_Haswell_4771_CPU.jpg "Enlarge")

Intel Haswell i7-4771 CPU, sitting atop its original packaging that contains
an OEM fan-cooled [heatsink](/wiki/Heatsink "Heatsink")

  * All models support: _[MMX](/wiki/MMX_\(instruction_set\) "MMX \(instruction set\)"), [SSE](/wiki/Streaming_SIMD_Extensions "Streaming SIMD Extensions"), [SSE2](/wiki/SSE2 "SSE2"), [SSE3](/wiki/SSE3 "SSE3"), [SSSE3](/wiki/SSSE3 "SSSE3"), [SSE4.1](/wiki/SSE4.1 "SSE4.1"), [SSE4.2](/wiki/SSE4.2 "SSE4.2"), [F16C](/wiki/F16C "F16C"), Enhanced Intel [SpeedStep](/wiki/SpeedStep "SpeedStep") Technology (EIST), [Intel 64](/wiki/Intel_64 "Intel 64"), XD bit (an [NX bit](/wiki/NX_bit "NX bit") implementation), [Intel VT-x](/wiki/Intel_VT-x "Intel VT-x"),_ and _[Smart Cache](/wiki/Smart_Cache "Smart Cache")._
    * Core i3, i5 and i7 support _[AVX](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions "Advanced Vector Extensions"), [AVX2](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions_2 "Advanced Vector Extensions 2"), BMI1, BMI2, [FMA3](/wiki/FMA3 "FMA3"),_ and _[AES-NI](/wiki/AES_instruction_set "AES instruction set")._[78]
    * Core i3 and i7, as well as the Core i5-4570T and i5-4570TE, support _[Hyper-Threading](/wiki/Hyper-Threading "Hyper-Threading") (HT)_.[78]
    * Core i5 and i7 support _[Turbo Boost](/wiki/Turbo_Boost "Turbo Boost") 2.0._[78]
    * Although it was initially supported on selected models, since August 2014 desktop variants no longer support _[TSX](/wiki/Transactional_Synchronization_Extensions "Transactional Synchronization Extensions")_ due to a bug that was discovered in its implementation; as a workaround, a microcode update disabled the TSX feature.[33][35][36][78]
    * SKUs below 45xx as well as R-series and K-series SKUs do not support _[Trusted Execution Technology](/wiki/Trusted_Execution_Technology "Trusted Execution Technology")_ or _[vPro](/wiki/Intel_vPro "Intel vPro")._[78]
    * _[Intel VT-d](/wiki/Intel_VT-d "Intel VT-d")_ , which is Intel's [IOMMU](/wiki/IOMMU "IOMMU"), is supported on all i5 and i7 SKUs except the i5-4670K and i7-4770K.[78][79][80] Support for VT-d requires the chipset and motherboard to also support VT-d.
    * Models i5-4690K and i7-4790K, codenamed Devil's Canyon, have a better internal [thermal grease](/wiki/Thermal_grease "Thermal grease") to help heat escape and an improved internal [voltage regulator](/wiki/Voltage_regulator "Voltage regulator") ("FIVR"), to help deliver cleaner power in situations like overclocking.
  * Transistors: 1.4 billion[81][82]
  * [Die](/wiki/Die_\(integrated_circuit\) "Die \(integrated circuit\)") size: 177 mm2[81]
  * [Intel HD and Iris Graphics](/wiki/Intel_HD_and_Iris_Graphics#Haswell "Intel HD and Iris Graphics") in following variants: 
    * R-series desktop processors feature Intel Iris Pro 5200 graphics (GT3e).[83]
    * All other currently known i3, i5 and i7 desktop processors include Intel HD 4600 graphics (GT2).[84]
    * The exceptions are processors 41xxx, which include HD 4400 graphics (GT2).
    * Celeron and Pentium processors contain Intel HD Graphics (GT1).
  * Pentium G3258, also known as the _Pentium Anniversary Edition_ , has an unlocked multiplier. Its release marks 20 years of "Pentium" as a brand.[85]

    b This feature also requires a chipset that supports VT-d like the Q87 chipset or the X99 chipset.

SKU suffixes to denote:

  * K – unlocked (adjustable CPU multiplier up to 63x)
    * The Pentium G3258 CPU is unlocked despite not having the K-suffix.
  * S – performance-optimized lifestyle (low power with 65 W TDP)
  * T – power-optimized lifestyle (ultra low power with 35–45 W TDP)
  * R – BGA packaging / High-performance GPU (currently Iris Pro 5200 (GT3e))
  * X – extreme edition (adjustable CPU ratio with no ratio limit)

### Server
processors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Server processors")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Intel_Xeon_E3-1241_v3_CPU.jpg/180px-
Intel_Xeon_E3-1241_v3_CPU.jpg)](/wiki/File:Intel_Xeon_E3-1241_v3_CPU.jpg)

Intel Xeon E3-1241 v3 CPU, on top of its original packaging with an OEM fan-
cooled heatsink

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Intel_Xeon_E5-1650_v3_CPU.jpg/180px-
Intel_Xeon_E5-1650_v3_CPU.jpg)](/wiki/File:Intel_Xeon_E5-1650_v3_CPU.jpg)

Intel Xeon E5-1650 v3 CPU; its retail box contains no OEM heatsink

  * All models support: _[MMX](/wiki/MMX_\(instruction_set\) "MMX \(instruction set\)"), [SSE](/wiki/Streaming_SIMD_Extensions "Streaming SIMD Extensions"), [SSE2](/wiki/SSE2 "SSE2"), [SSE3](/wiki/SSE3 "SSE3"), [SSSE3](/wiki/SSSE3 "SSSE3"), [SSE4.1](/wiki/SSE4.1 "SSE4.1"), [SSE4.2](/wiki/SSE4.2 "SSE4.2"), [AVX](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions "Advanced Vector Extensions") (Advanced Vector Extensions), [AVX2](/wiki/AVX2 "AVX2"), [FMA3](/wiki/FMA3 "FMA3"), [F16C](/wiki/F16C "F16C"), BMI (Bit Manipulation Instructions 1)+BMI2, Enhanced Intel [SpeedStep](/wiki/SpeedStep "SpeedStep") Technology (EIST), [Intel 64](/wiki/Intel_64 "Intel 64"), XD bit (an [NX bit](/wiki/NX_bit "NX bit") implementation), [TXT](/wiki/Trusted_Execution_Technology "Trusted Execution Technology"), [Intel vPro](/wiki/Intel_vPro "Intel vPro"), [Intel VT-x](/wiki/Intel_VT-x "Intel VT-x"), [Intel VT-d](/wiki/Intel_VT-d "Intel VT-d"), [hyper-threading](/wiki/Hyper-threading "Hyper-threading") (except E3-1220 v3 and E3-1225 v3), [Turbo Boost](/wiki/Turbo_Boost "Turbo Boost") 2.0, [AES-NI](/wiki/AES_instruction_set "AES instruction set")_, and _Smart Cache._
  * Haswell-EX models (E7-48xx/88xx v3) support _[TSX](/wiki/Transactional_Synchronization_Extensions "Transactional Synchronization Extensions")_ , while for Haswell-E, Haswell-WS (E3-12xx v3) and Haswell-EP (E5-16xx/26xx v3) models it was disabled via a microcode update in August 2014, due to a bug that was discovered in the TSX implementation.[35][36]
  * Transistors: 5.56 billion[90]
  * Die size: 661 mm2[90]

The first digit of the model number designates the largest supported multi-
socket configuration; thus, E5-26xx v3 models support up to dual-socket
configurations, while the E7-48xx v3 and E7-88xx v3 models support up to quad-
and eight-socket configurations, respectively. Also, E5-16xx/26xx v3 and
E7-48xx/88xx v3 models have no integrated GPU.

Lists of launched server processors are below, split between Haswell E3-12xx
v3, E5-16xx/26xx v3 and E7-48xx/88xx v3 models.

### Mobile
processors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Haswell_\(microarchitecture\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Mobile processors")]

  * All models support: _[MMX](/wiki/MMX_\(instruction_set\) "MMX \(instruction set\)"), [SSE](/wiki/Streaming_SIMD_Extensions "Streaming SIMD Extensions"), [SSE2](/wiki/SSE2 "SSE2"), [SSE3](/wiki/SSE3 "SSE3"), [SSSE3](/wiki/SSSE3 "SSSE3"), [SSE4.1](/wiki/SSE4.1 "SSE4.1"), [SSE4.2](/wiki/SSE4.2 "SSE4.2"), F16C, Enhanced Intel [SpeedStep](/wiki/SpeedStep "SpeedStep") Technology (EIST), [Intel VT-x](/wiki/Intel_VT-x "Intel VT-x"), [Intel 64](/wiki/Intel_64 "Intel 64"), XD bit (an [NX bit](/wiki/NX_bit "NX bit") implementation)_, and _Smart Cache._
    * Core i3, i5 and i7 support _[AVX](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions "Advanced Vector Extensions"), [AVX2](/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions_2 "Advanced Vector Extensions 2"), BMI1, BMI2, [FMA3](/wiki/FMA3 "FMA3")_, and _[hyper-threading](/wiki/Hyper-threading "Hyper-threading") (HT)_.
    * Core i3, i5 and i7 except the Core i3-4000M support _[AES-NI](/wiki/AES_instruction_set "AES instruction set")_.[95]
    * Core i5 and i7 except the Core i5-4410E, i5-4402EC, i7-4700EC, and i7-4702EC support _[Turbo Boost](/wiki/Turbo_Boost "Turbo Boost") 2.0._
  * Platform Controller Hub (PCH) integrated into the CPU package, slightly reducing the amount of space used on motherboards.[96]
  * Transistors: 1.3 billion[97]
  * Die size: 181 mm2[97]

  2. This is the processor's rated frequency and TDP.[98]:71–72
  3. When extra cooling is available, this mode specifies a higher TDP and higher guaranteed frequency versus the nominal mode.[98]:71–72

SKU suffixes to denote:

  * M – mobile processor ([Socket G3](/wiki/Intel_Socket_G3 "Intel Socket G3"))
  * Q – quad-core
  * U – ultra-low power (BGA1168 packaging)
  * X – "extreme"
  * Y – extreme low-power (BGA1168 packaging)
  * E / H – BGA1364 packaging
